Title.evidence: Effect of a Standardized Handoff Curriculum on Interclinician Communication: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Participants.evidence: Participants included 106 clinicians (residents, fellows, advance-practice clinicians, and attending physicians) across 1488 handoff events.

Intervention.evidence: The UW-IPASS curriculum was compared to standard handoff practices.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the UW-IPASS standardized handoff curriculum's effect on communication and patient outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the perceived adequacy of interclinician communication, assessed over eight months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was by cluster, with allocation concealment not specified.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants included 106 clinicians (residents, fellows, advance-practice clinicians, and attending physicians) across 1488 handoff events.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 63 residents and advance practice clinicians, 13 fellows, and 30 attending physicians participated.

Result_Outcome.evidence: 10.2% of handoffs were reported as poor quality, compared to 7.2% during the UW-IPASS period (odds ratio, 0.19; 95% CI, 0.03-0.74; P = .03).
